name: Tomato Late Blight
description: Caused by the fungus Phytophthora infestans. Appears as pale green, water-soaked spots on leaves.

stages.Advanced: Lesions enlarge, turning brown to black, with a white moldy growth on the underside of leaves.

causes: The oomycete Phytophthora infestans, which thrives in cool, moist conditions.
risk_factors: High humidity (>90%), cool temperatures (60-70°F / 15-21°C), and prolonged leaf wetness.
preventive_measures: Ensure proper spacing for air circulation, water at the base of plants, use resistant varieties, and rotate crops.
solution: Apply fungicides containing mancozeb or chlorothalonil. Ensure proper spacing for air circulation and avoid overhead watering.

name: Powdery Mildew
description: A fungal disease that affects a wide variety of plants, appearing as white powdery spots on leaves and stems.

stages.Initial: Small, white, powdery spots on the upper surface of leaves.
stages.Advanced: The powdery spots spread to cover entire leaves, stems, and sometimes flowers and fruit. Leaves may turn yellow and fall off.

causes: Various species of fungi in the order Erysiphales. Spores are spread by wind.
risk_factors: High humidity at night, low humidity during the day, poor air circulation, and crowded planting.
preventive_measures: Choose resistant varieties, ensure good air circulation, and avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen.
solution: Apply fungicides like potassium bicarbonate, neem oil, or sulfur. Prune affected areas to improve air circulation.

name: Ringworm (Tinea Corporis)
description: A common fungal infection of the skin. Not caused by a worm.

stages.Initial: A red, itchy, scaly patch on the skin.
stages.Developed: The patch develops into a distinct ring-shape with a raised border.

causes: Dermatophyte fungi, commonly transmitted through direct contact with an infected person or animal.
risk_factors: Weakened immune system, excessive sweating, participating in contact sports, and sharing contaminated items like towels.
preventive_measures: Keep skin clean and dry, avoid sharing personal items, and wear loose-fitting clothing.
solution: Apply over-the-counter antifungal creams, lotions, or powders like clotrimazole or miconazole for 2 to 4 weeks. Keep the skin clean and dry.
